554.title: Bayes' rule: Probability form
554.clickbait: The original formulation of Bayes' rule.
554.text:
The original formulation of [1lz] runs as follows:

$$\mathbb P(H_i\mid e) = \dfrac{\mathbb P(e\mid H_i) \cdot \mathbb P(H_i)}{\sum_k \mathbb P(e\mid H_k) \cdot \mathbb P(H_k)} \tag{1}$$

where $H_i$ is a hypothesis, $e$ is a piece of evidence, and $H_k$ is a set of [-1rd] hypotheses that contains $H_i.$

The easiest way to understand this formulation is to recall the [1x5 odds form] of Bayes' rule, which states

$$\frac{\mathbb P(H_i \mid e)}{\mathbb P(H_j \mid e)} = \frac{\mathbb P(H_i)}{\mathbb P(H_j)} \times \frac{\mathbb P(e \mid H_i)}{\mathbb P(e \mid H_j)}. \tag{2}$$

Equation (1) is just equation (2) restricted to the case where the alternative hypothesis $H_j$ is the hypothesis "anything except $H_i$ is true", and the posterior odds have been converted into a posterior probability (which is always allowed in this case, because $H_i$ and $H_j$ are [-1rd]).

For a proof that (1) follows from (2), see [555].

# Interpretation: who predicted best?

Imagine each hypothesis $H_1,H_2,H_3\ldots$ as an expert with a lump of clay. The total amount of clay is one kilogram, and each expert $H_k$ has been allocated a $\mathbb P(H_k)$ portion of that kilogram. (For example, if $\mathbb P(H_5)=\frac{1}{5}$ then expert 5 has been allocated 200 grams of clay.)

The experts are competing in a game that works as follows. We're going to make a series of observations. There are lots of possible observations $e_1, e_2, e_3, \ldots$ Before we make each observation, the experts place their clay on a board which has the labels "$e_1$", "$e_2$", "$e_3$", and so on written on it. They place their clay on that board, and then we check what the real observation is. Our goal is to figure out which expert understands how our observations actually work.

(In practice, the experts might be "scientific hypotheses," and we might be trying to figure out which hypothesis actually explains the data in front of us.)

Bayes' rule tells us how to find the best expert. Here's what it says: The numerator of equation (1) says that the posterior probability of $H_i$ given $e$ should be proportional to the prior probability of $H_i,$ times the degree to which $H_i$ predicted $e.$ In other words, _experts are only allowed to keep the clay that they placed on the observation that actually happened._ If the actual observation was $e_7,$ then $H_i$ has to throw away all their clay _except_ the clay that they placed on $e_7.$

However, everybody else _also_ has to throw away the clay that they failed to place on $e_7.$ The denominator of equation (1) says that after everyone has thrown away their clay, we rescale all remaining clay, while preserving the _relative_ size of each lump, until the total amount of clay is back to 1kg.

$\sum_k \mathbb P(e_7 \mid H_k) \cdot \mathbb P(H_k)$ is the total amount of clay left after everyone has thrown away the clay that they failed to place on observation $e_7$, and we can think of it as a weighted average (weighted by prior probability) of how well all the other experts predicted $e_7.$ $H_i$ does well if it predicted $e_7$ better than average; it does poorly otherwise.

Which experts gain the most? The ones who placed _all_ their clay on $e_7.$ They don't have to throw away any of their initial clay, and then they benefit from the rescaling that happens when other experts lose clay. But placing all your mass on one observation is a risky proposition: For if some _other_ observation (say, $e_3$) happened, then they'd throw away _all_ their clay, and they'd be out of the game entirely. Once an expert's amount of clay goes to zero, there's no way for them to recover. That hypothesis is done, dead, and removed from the game.

So what does the probabilistic form of Bayes' rule tell us about how to update our beliefs? It tells us that the probability mass of a hypothesis should be _conserved_ — make each hypothesis allocate all its probability mass in advance, and make each hypothesis throw away all the mass that it failed to put on the true hypothesis. If hypotheses want to gain some of that lost mass back, they have to predict the world better than the alternatives and then gain from the rescaling.

It also tells us that, when you see new evidence $e,$ then the question "does this support hypothesis $H_i$?" depends on how well $H_i$ predicted $e$ _compared to the competition._ It's not enough for $H_i$ to predict $e$ well if every other hypothesis also predicted $e$ well (i.e., your theory of physics gets no points for predicting that the sky is blue), $H_i$ only goes up in probability when it predicts $e$ better than the alternatives.

In other words, when you see evidence $e,$ the hypothesis that _best predicted $e$_ is the one that should get the most points. If you get in a car accident, and don't want to relinquish the hypothesis that you're a great driver, then you can find all sorts of reasons ("the road was slippery! my car freaked out!") why $\mathbb P(e \mid GoodDriver)$ is not too low. But $\mathbb P(e \mid BadDriver)$ is also part of the update equation, and the "bad driver" hypothesis better predicts the evidence. Thus, your first impulse, when deciding how to update your beliefs in the face of a car accident, should not be "But my preferred hypothesis allows for this evidence!" It should instead be "Points to the 'bad driver' hypothesis for predicting this evidence better than the alternatives!" (and remember to [incremental_updating update your beliefs incrementally] — you're allowed to increase the probability of $BadDriver$ a little bit, while still thinking that it's unlikely).

1ln.editSummary: alias. note to self: come back and explain new requisites system.
1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1lw.title: Mathematics
1lw.clickbait: Mathematics is the study of numbers and other ideal objects that can be described by axioms.

1lz.title: Bayes' rule
1lz.clickbait: Bayes' rule is the core theorem of probability theory saying how to revise our beliefs when we make a new observation.

1r5.title: Math 1
1r5.clickbait: Is math sometimes fun for you, and are you not anxious if you see a math puzzle you don't know how to solve?

1r6.title: Math 2
1r6.clickbait: Do you work with math on a fairly routine basis?  Do you have little trouble grasping abstract structures and ideas?

1rd.title: Mutually exclusive and exhaustive
1rd.clickbait: The condition needed for probabilities to sum to 1

1rj.title: Conditional probability
1rj.clickbait: The notation for writing "The probability that someone has green eyes, if we know that they have red hair."

1rm.title: Prior probability
1rm.clickbait: What we believed before seeing the evidence.

1rp.title: Posterior probability
1rp.clickbait: What we believe, after seeing the evidence and doing a Bayesian update.

1rt.title: Arbital path
1rt.clickbait: Arbital path is a linear sequence of pages tailored specifically to teach a given concept to a user.

1x5.title: Bayes' rule: Odds form
1x5.clickbait: The simplest and most easily understandable form of Bayes' rule uses relative odds.

1y9.title: Probability notation for Bayes' rule
1y9.clickbait: The probability notation used in Bayesian reasoning

1zg.title: Bayes' rule: Vector form
1zg.clickbait: For when you want to apply Bayes' rule to lots of evidence and lots of variables, all in one go. (This is more or less how spam filters work.)

3d.title: Arbital
3d.clickbait: Arbital is the place for crowdsourced, intuitive math explanations.

3hs.title: Author's guide to Arbital
3hs.clickbait: How to write intuitive, flexible content on Arbital.

3n.title: Arbital "parent" relationship
3n.clickbait: Parent-child relationship between pages implies a strong, inseparable connection.

56j.title: Proof of Bayes' rule: Probability form
